00005 """gypsh output module
00006 
00007 gypsh is a GYP shell.  It's not really a generator per se.  All it does is
00008 fire up an interactive Python session with a few local variables set to the
00009 variables passed to the generator.  Like gypd, it's intended as a debugging
00010 aid, to facilitate the exploration of .gyp structures after being processed
00011 by the input module.
00012 
00013 The expected usage is "gyp -f gypsh -D OS=desired_os".
00014 """
00015 
00016 
00017 import code
00018 import sys
00019 
00020 
00021 # All of this stuff about generator variables was lovingly ripped from gypd.py.
00022 # That module has a much better description of what's going on and why.
00023 _generator_identity_variables = [
00024   'EXECUTABLE_PREFIX',
00025   'EXECUTABLE_SUFFIX',
00026   'INTERMEDIATE_DIR',
00027   'PRODUCT_DIR',
00028   'RULE_INPUT_ROOT',
00029   'RULE_INPUT_DIRNAME',
00030   'RULE_INPUT_EXT',
00031   'RULE_INPUT_NAME',
00032   'RULE_INPUT_PATH',
00033   'SHARED_INTERMEDIATE_DIR',
00034 ]
00035 
00036 generator_default_variables = {
00037 }
00038 
00039 for v in _generator_identity_variables:
00040   generator_default_variables[v] = '<(%s)' % v
00041 
00042 
00043 def GenerateOutput(target_list, target_dicts, data, params):
00044   locals = {
00045         'target_list':  target_list,
00046         'target_dicts': target_dicts,
00047         'data':         data,
00048       }
00049 
00050   # Use a banner that looks like the stock Python one and like what
00051   # code.interact uses by default, but tack on something to indicate what
00052   # locals are available, and identify gypsh.
00053   banner='Python %s on %s\nlocals.keys() = %s\ngypsh' % \
00054          (sys.version, sys.platform, repr(sorted(locals.keys())))
00055 
00056   code.interact(banner, local=locals)
